docs.lead_paragraph: Maine's innovative effort to reduce prescription drug costs for uninsured state residents by pressuring manufacturers to grant price rebates received the Supreme Court's qualified approval today. The 6-to-3 decision lifted an injunction that has kept the Maine Rx Program from taking effect since the state's Legislature enacted it in 2000. The court's action is likely to shift the drug pricing debate away from the courts and back to the executive branch and the states.

headline.main: Justices Allow Drug-Cost Plan To Go Forward

docs.abstract: Supreme Court gives qualified approval to Maine's innovative effort to reduce prescription drug costs for uninsured state residents; 6-to-3 decision lifts injunction that has kept Maine Rx Program from taking effect since state's Legislature enacted it in 2000; decision is likely to shift drug pricing debate away from courts and back to executive branch and states; earlier ruling by Federal District Court, in suit brought by pharmaceutical industry, found program violates federal Medicaid statute and constitutional proscription against state interference with interstate commerce; other states are following Maine case closely; 29 states filed Supreme Court brief on Maine's behalf; about half the states have started experimenting with ways to hold down costs for various groups of consumers; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Maine's innovative effort to reduce prescription drug costs for uninsured state residents by pressuring manufacturers to grant price rebates received the Supreme Court's qualified approval today.    The 6-to-3 decision lifted an injunction that has...

docs.lead_paragraph: They were billed as near wonder drugs, much safer and more effective in treating schizophrenia than anything that had come before. For many years, it seemed that the excitement was fully warranted.

headline.main: Leading Drugs for Psychosis Come Under New Scrutiny

docs.abstract: Researchers suggest that new generation of antipsychotic drugs, called atypicals, may not be as effective as first thought when they were introduced 14 years ago, and may have dangerous side effects; studies find their superiority is at best modest, specific to certain symptoms and variable from drug to drug; there is increasing suspicion that they may cause serious side effects, notably diabetes, in some cases leading to death; issue of risks has become more pressing as drugs are prescribed for children and for adults with milder conditions; experts say drugs' benefits must be balanced by side effects and cost; more than 15 million prescriptions were written last year for Zyprexa and Risperdal, two leading drugs; when first introduced, they appeared so successful in treating psychotic illness that doctors began prescribing them for other conditions, including nonpsychotic depression, conduct disorder and severe aggression in children; detailed look at drugs' growth since 1990; photo; graphs; charts (L)
docs.snippet: They were billed as near wonder drugs, much safer and more effective in treating schizophrenia than anything that had come before.    For many years, it seemed that the excitement was fully warranted.

docs.lead_paragraph: After the State Legislature passed a New York City aid package yesterday over the veto of Gov. George E. Pataki, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg reversed course and said that the city would be able to save two of the eight city firehouses that were scheduled to close. The mayor's turnaround came after he and his aides insisted for months that the closing of the firehouses was politically difficult, but necessary, and that the firehouses would have to be closed even if Albany came up with the help they sought.

headline.main: Mayor Spares 2 Threatened Firehouses After All

docs.abstract: Mayor Bloomberg reverses course and says that New York City will be able to save two of eight city firehouses that were scheduled to close; acts after State Legislature passes aid package for city over veto of Gov George Pataki; firehouses to be spared are Engine 293 in Woodhaven, Queens, and Squad 252 in Bushwick, Brooklyn; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: RENWICK QUESADA and his fiancée, Liz Mucelli, plan to get married in September at the Hammond Museum in North Salem. As the Connecticut couple perused a list of florists, photographers and musicians that the museum gave them, they noticed the names of available clergy, and gave the Rev. Janice Arlene Rost a call. After meeting her, they chose Ms. Rost, who was ordained in 1989 by the New Seminary in Manhattan, to perform the ceremony. ''I was raised Catholic and my fiancée was raised Unitarian, so it made sense to go interfaith,'' said Mr. Quesada. ''We don't really practice religion, anyway. The key thing was to get someone we felt comfortable with and be able to create our own ceremony.''
docs.abstract: Article on freelance clergy, many of them retired ministers who have left church to change careers or women and gay men barred from official positions in traditional religions, who can be hired for weddings, funerals and other occasions; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As a doctoral student who also serves as a T.A., I am satisfied with the deal I get, which covers my tuition and pays me a modest stipend. (It does not cover health care, but it does subsidize a portion of my insurance premium.) I do resent the self-serving argument of some university administrators and senior professors, however, that T.A.-ing is an apprenticeship and that unionizing would hurt the ''collegiality'' of the student-teacher relationship: they don't do their jobs for love; they bargain for higher pay; and it is hypocritical to expect us not to do the same. Sumita Pahwa Johns Hopkins University Baltimore
docs.abstract: Sumita Pahwa letter argues that it is hypocritical to suggest that unionization of graduate students would hurt relationship between them and professors (May 4, Daniel Duane article)

docs.lead_paragraph: Amy and Kevin Degnan were just the kind of people this small and ever-shrinking city needed. They were young and college-educated. They hoped to buy a house. That was the plan, anyway, when they moved here from Buffalo two years ago. Mrs. Degnan was fresh out of graduate school at the State University at Buffalo with a degree in library science, and she got a job at the local library.

headline.main: Hard Times Get Harder Upstate As Fiscal Crisis Spans New York

docs.abstract: New York State's sagging economy and money troubles are taking grim toll in central part of state, where cities like Elmira and counties like Chemung are facing tough times as fiscal woes trickle down to localities; area is already depressed by post-1990's bust, which depleted local tax base and increased unemployment (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: CALL it a sudden reversal. Two months ago, Terence M. O'Sullivan was part of a lonely minority on the board of Ullico, the union-owned insurer, and was badly outvoted when he sought to require the directors to return profits from a stock trading deal that is the subject of four investigations. That deal has become an embarrassment to organized labor because 17 Ullico directors, most of them past and present union presidents, are being investigated for making more than $6 million in profits from what some investigators suggest was illegal insider trading.
docs.abstract: Terence M O'Sullivan is elected chairman and chief executive of Ullico, union-owned insurer, after he plays major behind-the-scenes role in forging new slate of directors that vows to restore integrity to company; 17 former Ullico directors are being investigated for making more than $6 million in profits from what some investigators suggest was illegal insider trading; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MOST homeowners are aware that under current tax law, as much as $500,000 in gain realized from the sale of a principal residence owned and used for at least two years may be exempt from taxation. (The $500,000 exemption is the maximum exclusion for a married couple filing jointly; taxpayers filing individually get an exemption of up to $250,000.) There are times, however, when the gain on the sale of a home or an apartment is subject to tax. One such situation occurs when the taxpayer has not owned the property or lived in it for the require amount of time. Another is when the home being sold is a second or vacation home.
docs.abstract: Advice for property owners on ways to avoid or reduce capital gains taxes on sale of vacation home or home not used as principal residence for at least two years; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: PAUL MIGNONE'S head was killing him. Suffering from a weeklong migraine headache and a sinus infection, Mr. Mignone, 39, walked into the First Aid Immediate Care Medical Center in Trumbull hoping to see a doctor quickly.

headline.main: The Privacy Practice: Sign Here and Here

docs.abstract: Article on changes that doctors, hospitals, pharmacies and health organizations across Connecticut are putting into place as result of new federal guidelines aimed at protecting patients' privacy; photos (M)
docs.snippet: PAUL MIGNONE'S head was killing him.    Suffering from a weeklong migraine headache and a sinus infection, Mr. Mignone, 39, walked into the First Aid Immediate Care Medical Center in Trumbull hoping to see a doctor quickly.

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER Amy Donnelly's husband lost his job last December as a toolmaker for a small manufacturing company, the couple decided not to continue their health insurance under the federal law, known as Cobra, that lets workers keep their policies for up to 18 months if they pay full premiums. The monthly cost, $850, seemed too steep, they said, and they thought they could get a better rate on their own. But Mrs. Donnelly, 40, said no one would sell a policy covering the couple and their 8-year-old son. The reason, she said she was told, was her diabetes. Mrs. Donnelly, who lives in Manchester, Conn., is one of a small but growing number of people who are considered uninsurable because they have pre-existing medical conditions like diabetes or heart disease.

headline.main: Warning Signs At the High-Risk Pool

docs.abstract: Comment on problems with state-run high-risk insurance pools set to to guarantee health insurance coverage to consumers with potentially costly ailments (M)
